She applied for a loan of 50,000 YER to buy more clothes so as to expand her business. She hopes that she can use the profits she will make to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy more clothes so as to expand her business.

loans.name: Precilla

texts.en:
Precilla lives in the West Point area. She is single and has 2 children, who are in school and live at home. Precilla did not attend school. 

For the past four years, she has been involved in the sale of rice by the cup in the local market. Her main challenge is the large amount of competition, but she manages to make some profit. Precilla has requested this loan to purchase more rice by the bag. In the future, she would like to buy some land and build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more rice by the bag.

loans.name: Upendo Group

texts.en:
BRIGITER, who is in her early 40s, is married with two children who are still at school. She has several businesses. She runs a beauty salon and has a wholesale soft drinks business. She has been in these businesses for twelve years now. She works from 7.00 am to 8.00 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be BRIGITER's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which she will use for replacing missing items in the salon business and to increase the wholesale soft drinks business. She dreams of building her own house.

BRIGITER will share this loan with her loan group "UPENDO" which has five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the the loan.

loans.use: to replace the missing items in the salon business and to increase on the wholesale soft drinks business.

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en: Parviz is 21 years old. He is a purposeful young man. He studies at the Medical University of Tajikistan. Parviz is studying the fourth course. He studies well. After lessons he works at night at the hospital as a nurse. In this way he earns his living, as his parents are poor people. He dreams that, after graduating from the university, he will be a good doctor able to treat all illness. Parviz is not married. He must to pay for his tuition at the Medical University for the fourth course but he does not have the money for it. He is asking for a loan of 900 USD to pay his tuition. He is a kind young man, so it is good to support him.

loans.use: To pay for his tuition.

loans.name: Abel

texts.en:
Abel is 25 years old and is from Nyahururu. He is married to Beatrice who is a business lady and they are blessed with one child aged 10 months.

Abel has been running his business of selling clothes for the past year. To enable him buy more stock of clothes, shoes and handbags to sell to his customers, he has applied for his first loan of 80,000 KES from Kadet Ltd.

His monthly income right now is 30,000 KES and he intends to use the anticipated profits from his expanded business to pay back his loan to Kadet Ltd., and to buy more merchandise for his boutique shop.

His hopes and dreams for his future business and family are to prosper and to excel.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of clothes, shoes and handbags to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 37 years old and is from Olkalou. He is married to Pauline and they are blessed with five children, ages 13, 9, 7, 5 and 3 years old.

Joseph is in the business of mixed farming, which he has been doing for the past six years. To enable him buy farm supplies like fertilizer, planting seeds and pesticides, he has applied for his fourth loan of 70,000 KES from Kadet Ltd.

His monthly income right now is 30,000 KES, and his plan is to use profits realized from his expanded business to pay his loan back to Kadet Ltd., to educate his children and to buy some livestock.

In the future, he hopes to be an established farmer in his area.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies like planting seeds, fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Dienaba's Group

texts.fr:
Créer le 12 Juillet 2008 ce groupe au sein du banc villageois compte 26 femmes qui toutes s’activent dans des activités génératrices de revenu plus particulièrement le petit commerce et la transformation de produits. Elles vivent dans le même village et entretiennent des liens de solidarité très développés. 

Madame Diénabou  (assise à l’extrême gauche avec une main levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette  du groupe. Elle est âgée de  53 ans, mariée et mère de cinq  enfants dont 02 garçons et trois filles. Elle s’active dans la transformation de céréales : mil, maïs pour en faire du couscous et son destinés à la vente. De même elle fait de la transformation de bissap, gingembre et divers autres fruits suivant les saisons.

Avec son nouveau prêt elle compte acheter 10 sacs de mil à 5 000 Fr CFA le sac, 10 de maïs au même prix, un sac de feuille de bissap, 30 kilos de gingembre, 02 sacs de sucres 04 bassines, 12 tamis à 300 F r CFA pièce.

Les profits tirés de son activité l’aiderons continuer la construction de sa maison d’une part et d’autre part  soutenir son mari dans les charges scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
Created on July 12, 2008, this group within the 'banc villageois' is composed of 26 women who are all active in revenue-generating businesses, especially in small-scale commerce and producing food products. The women live in the same village and maintain ties of solidarity to a high degree.

Ms. Diénabou (sitting at the far left with her hand raised) is the featured borrower of the group. She is 53 years old, married, and the mother of five children (two boys and three girls). She is active in the processing of grains: millet and corn for making couscous to be sold. She also processes hibiscus, ginger, and a variety of other produce according to the season.

With her new loan, she intends to purchase 10 sacks of millet at 5,000 francs CFA per sack; 10 of corn at the same price; a sack of hibiscus; 30 kg of ginger; 2 sacks of sugar; 4 basins; and 12 sieves at 300 francs each. 

The profits earned from her business will help her to continue building her house, and part of the profits will help her husband to cover the children's schooling costs.

loans.use: to purchase millet, corn, hibiscus, ginger, sugar, basins, and sieves

loans.name: Mahulome6 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MAHULOME6 est composé de trois personnes qui sont des amies et s'approvisionne au même endroit. La représentante du groupe nommée Hélène (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 35 ans. Hélène n’a pas fréquentée l'école. Hélène est mariée à un chauffeur nommé Nassirou. Le couple a deux enfants, dont un scolarisé et un reste à leur charge. Hélène vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Les charges de ménage sont supportées par Hélène et son mari. Pour ce faire, Hélène vend divers articles (huile d'arachide) et des céréales (maïs, mil, riz) depuis douze ans dans sa région. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, et de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle Hélène ensemble avec les  autres membres du groupe MAHULOME6 sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
The MAHULOME6 group is comprised of three friends who get their supplies from the same place. The group representative named Hélène (who has her hand raised in the photo) is 35 years old. Hélène did not go to school. Helen is married to a driver named Nassirou. The couple has two children - one who goes to school and one who stays at home. Hélène lives with her husband and children. 

Hélène and her husband take care of the household expenses. In order to do this, Hélène has been selling various items (peanut oil) and cereals (corn, millet, rice) for 12 years in her region. With the goal of strengthening her business and satisfying the needs of her clients, Hélène and the other members of MAHULOME6 are asking for a sixth loan with ALIDé. The previous loans have been repaid.

loans.use: buy cereals (corn, millet, rice) and peanut oil.

loans.name: Anush

texts.en:
Anush was born in Yerevan city. After school she entered the Yerevan State Linguistic University and she graduated in the department of English and German Languages. Soon after getting married she moved to Kapan city which is in Syunik region. Now she is a mother of three sons who are still school-aged. Her husband works in the military sphere. 

For thirteen years, Anush worked at the local school as a teacher of English Language and Literature, and she also gives paid courses of English Language and prepares pupils for entrance examinations. 
  
Anush is asking for a loan of 850,000 Armenian drams in order to buy a computer and some necessary literature which she needs for her courses with pupils at home.

loans.use: to buy a computer and some necessary literature which she needs for her courses at home with pupils.

loans.name: Gagik

texts.en:
Gagik lives and works in Kapan city, which is in the Syunik region. He lives with his retired mother. He is divorced and his two children live with his ex-wife. Gagik, despite having a specialty as a lawyer, now he is a singer. He used to have a band and he went on tour to almost all the towns in Armenia and the Nagorno-Karabakh Republic. Now he mainly sings on weddings, birthdays and at corporate parties. 

He has dealt with Kiva before and now he needs a loan in order to record a new song, which as he says today is very popular and liked very much by his admirers. He thanks Kiva lenders very much since their support gives him a chance as a singer to become famous and popular as a singer.

Gagaik is asking for a loan of 700,000 Armenian drams in order to record a CD for which he has already prepared twelve nice songs.

loans.use: to record a CD for which he already has prepared twelve nice songs.

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.en:
Maria Teresa is a married woman with six children. She is a very working entrepreneur. She is 43 years old and has four children who are still in school.
She has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

Maria Teresa requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional ingredients like rice, coconut milk, sugar, etc. for her business. She has been in this business for 5 years. Maria Teresa would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients like rice, coconut milk, sugar, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn works hard to support her family. Marilyn is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Marilyn requested a PHP 14000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional fish to sell.

Marilyn has been in this business for 40 years now.

In the future, Marilyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is 48 years old and married with two children. Winnie works very hard to provide for them.

Winnie runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more goods to sell in her general store.

Winnie has been in this business for 21 years and sells a variety of items, such as canned goods, soft-drinks, snack foods, shampoos, detergent soaps, etc. 

In the future, Winnie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara is from Dasht village of Armavir region. She lives with her daughter and son. She works for the village local self governance body, and her daughter works in the village local library. They work hard to be able to earn a living. However, their salaries are so low that the family cannot afford a living based on those salaries alone. 

With the help of her family members, Tamara has a business cultivating beans, potatoes, cucumbers, beets, peaches, apricots, and apples. Her son assists her greatly in her everyday activities related to farming; he sells the agricultural products in the local market, which is an important source of  the family's income. To continue running her agribusiness in a sustainable way, Tamara needs a loan of 2,000 USD to purchase potatoes and wheat seeds, to buy fertilizer, and to pay for harvesting services. She and her family rely on the good will of the lenders and will greatly appreciate their support in collecting the needed loan amount to maintain and develop their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase potatoes and wheat seeds, to buy fertilizer, and to pay for harvesting services.

loans.name: Ap

texts.en:
Ap, a 33-year-old married mother of two children, lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. She and her husband have been running a store selling soft drinks, fruit juice and coffee for five years. Ap started this business to cover her expenses and to generate income to raise her children. 

Ap is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying more beverages and coffee to stock her store. She hopes that this will enable her to attract more customers and increase her turnover. She hopes that through the loan she will be able to expand her business activities and reinvest in her enterprise.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks and coffee to sell at her store.

loans.name: Suong

texts.en: Suong is requesting a new loan to expand her store by buying a range of products including food and beverages, purchases that will help her to better meet the needs of her customers. She hopes that her new loan will assist her in increasing both the size of her store and her sales, and will also help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy food and beverages to sell.

loans.name: Nhung

texts.en:
Nhung is 37 years old and married with one son and one daughter. She lives with her family in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City. She and her husband earn income making wheel polishing equipment.

They started their business ten years ago. Nhung intends to take a loan to gradually expand her business by buying a larger quantity of raw materials to produce wheel polishing equipment to better satisfy her customers. 

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy raw materials to produce wheel polishing equipment.

loans.name: Am

texts.en:
Am, 38, is single and earns an income making clothing, national flags and face masks. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. 

Am started her business eight years ago and is now requesting a loan to expand her business by buying a variety of cloth and sewing materials to increase her production and better satisfy her customers. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a variety of cloth and sewing materials

loans.name: Mevludi

texts.en:
Mevludi is a 64-year-old married man from the village of Chumlaki, East Georgia. He lives with his wife in his own house. Mevludi’s economic activity is a small-scale grocery store in his district where various food products are sold and there is a pharmacy. Mevludi works hard to run his business successfully but he still doesn’t have enough income to make savings and improve his standard of living.

He is very enthusiastic and has good business acumen. He has noticed a high demand for a dinner hall in his district. In response to the local market demand, he has requested credit to finance the costs of purchasing building materials and all the needed inventories for starting a dinner hall. He owns commercial space, and after renovation and furnishing, Mevludi will be able to host wedding parties, birthdays, etc. Local people will pay for using the hall and Mevludi will earn extra money.

He hopes this Kiva loan will be helpful for his family.

loans.use: to start up a dinner hall in his district.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is from the village of Velistsikhe. He is 39 years old, married, and lives with his wife, two school-age children, and retired father. George and his father are builders and work on special projects. Moreover, George grows grapes in his own vineyard, and sells the harvest in the fall season.
 
In order to generate more income for his family's well-being, George plans to start another business with the Kiva loan. If his loan is financed, George will purchase vine saplings, grow them, and sell the small trees next year in the fall when there is a planting season. George thinks his project will raise his income and the family will get good profit for next fall.

George hopes that Kiva loan will be helpful for his business .

loans.use: to purchase vine saplings to grow and sell in the planting season.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline lives in West Point. She is 35 years old, single, and has two children, ages 6 and 19 years old. Her children attend school and live at home. 

For four years, Pauline has been selling slippers in the local market. She received a small amount of money from her boyfriend to start her business. She likes her business because it helps her to support her children. She is requesting a loan to purchase more slippers for her  business. Her plan is to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more slippers for her business.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana, 30-year-old married woman from Tbilisi, the capital city of Georgia, lives with her husband and two children. Her husband works as a driver and earns 400 Gel per month, the family's sole source of income.

Nana decided to start her own business and has requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of $900 to start a trading business. Nana plans to go to Turkey and purchase a stock of clothing there. She is very motivated and ready to tackle all of the difficulties associated with beginning a new business.

loans.use: to begin selling clothes

loans.name: Rey De Reyes Group

texts.es: El grupo lo conforman tres socias trabajadoras una de ellas María  Xisela tiene la edad de 32 años, casada, con cuatro hijos, su negocio es la venta de tortillas desde hace 8 años en su domicilio. Tiene de ser cliente de la institución 1 año. El crédito lo está solicitado para compra de flete de leña, quintal de maíz, cal, molida. María del Carmen tiene 57 años su negocio es una pulpería  y un molino, Luz tiene 31 años su negocio es la venta de nacatamales.
texts.en: This group consists of three hardworking partners. One is María Xisela who is 32 and married with four children. Her business is selling tortillas which she has done for 8 years from her home. She has been a customer of this institution for one year. She requests this loan for a load of firewood, a bushel of corn, and ground lime. María del Carmen is 57 years old and her business is a grocery store and a mill. Luz is 31 years old and her business is selling nacatamales.

loans.use: to purchase a load of firewood, a bushel of corn, lime, and others.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy  is married with two children and both of her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members (her mother). She sells second hand clothes on a retail basis and has been in this business for 15 years. She works seven days a week.  

Prossy has applied for a loan of 800,000 UGX from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bales of second hand clothes. Her major business challenges include seasonality (the rainy season), which hinders her movements and transportation, and thieves. She aspires to have permanent business premises and also to become a wholesaler. She lives in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bales of used clothes.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 46 years old and lives in the town of Mpigi in the region of Kampala South in Uganda. He is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past eight years, Joseph has been working hard to manage his grocery shop, which sells general items. 

To help expand his business, Joseph has requested a loan of 3,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock of items for resale, and will help Joseph to generate greater profits and increase his sales and profits. Joseph hopes that in the future, he will be able to expand the business. 

Joseph is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joseph who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stock of items for resale.

loans.name: Mwangi

texts.en:
Mwangi's motorcycle transport business is doing well and he has successfully paid off his previous loan. He continues to support his parents and younger siblings.

Mwangi's proceeds have increased to a monthly income of 15,000 KES. He has been advanced a third loan of 40,000 KES, not to do business, but to furnish his house. This has been his desire for a while, and it will motivate him to work even harder so as to live a comfortable life. He is still in the transport business.

Mwangi plans to open a motorcycle spare parts shop in Narok town. His dream is to be financially stable.

loans.use: to furnish his house.

loans.name: Luong

texts.en:
Luong is 48 years old and is married. His wife is a small trader. He has been running a shop that fixes electrical appliances for 20 years. He started this business to cover his expenses and raise two daughters. They live in Ho Chi Minh City.

Luong is requesting a loan to expand his business by buying more electrical equipment to repair and sell. He hopes that by offering more products he will be able to increase the turnover of his business. 

He hopes that through the loan he will be able to expand his business activities and have money to reinvest in his business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more electrical equipment.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
Mabel is 30 years old and lives in West Point. She’s single and has three children, ages 5, 9 and 12 years old. Her children are presently in school and live at home. 

For the past three years, Mabel has been selling used clothes in the local market. She started this business with a small amount of money that she received from her children's father, and she learned the business from her mother. What she likes about this business is that it helps her to pay her children's school fees on time. She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. Her future plan is to save money and build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Precious

texts.en: Precious is 24 years old and lives in West Point. She is single and did not go to school. Over the past three years, she has been selling bread and soft drinks. She started this business with a small amount of money that she received from her mother and she learned the sales business from her mother. What she likes about this business is that it helps her to pay her house rent. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bread and soft drinks for her business.  Her future plan is to save money and build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more bread and soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Cam

texts.en: Cam, 46, is married and has four children. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. She and her husband earn an income running a soft-drink shop that they started 15 years ago. Cam is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying a greater variety of soft drinks to sell at her store and better satisfy her customers. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a greater variety of soft drinks for selling

loans.name: Mui

texts.en: Mui, 55, is single. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. Mui started selling salt 15 years ago. She is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying a greater variety and quantity of salt to sell at her store and better satisfy her customers. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy salt to sell.

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Huong is 50 years old and is married with two children. Her husband is a driver for hire. Huong has been running a food stall in front of her door for 20 years. She started this business to cover her expenses and to generate income to raise her children. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. Huong is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying more food ingredients and better quality food such as noodles and beef to attract more customers and increase the turnover of her business. She hopes that through the loan she will be able to expand her business activities and have money to reinvest in her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy food ingredients and better quality food such as noodles and beef.

loans.name: Dao

texts.en: Dao is 45 years old and is married with three children. Her husband is a driver for hire. Dao has been running a business of making clothing for 20 years. She started this business to cover her expenses and to generate income to raise her children. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. Dao is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying more cloth and sewing materials in order to make more clothing. She hopes that she will be able to attract more customers and increase the turnover of her business. She hopes that through the loan she will be able to have money to reinvest in her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy cloth and sewing materials

loans.name: Elgun

texts.en: Elgun is 26 years old, single and lives with his parents. His mother, Shamama, is a teacher. Elguns's father, Ismayil, doesn’t work at an income-generating business. He helps Elgun in his business. They have been IDP (Internally Displaced Persons) from Füzuli city for 20 years. Today they are living in a hostel in the Yasamal settlement of Abseron region. Elgun rents a shop where he sells vegetables and fruits like potatoes, onions, cucumbers, apple, bananas and other vegetables and fruits. For over six years, he has been at this business. Now Elgun is planning to increase his business. He needs 1,800 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat) to buy more fruits and vegetables. He thanks Komak and Kiva organization for a loan and aid. In the future, he wants to buy a store to increase his monthly income and he wants to get marries and have a big family.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Reyna

texts.es: Reyna de 25 años de edad, está casada con Segundo, quien se dedica al transporte, y es padre de su único hijo de 06 años de edad. Juntos habitan cómodamente en la casa de sus padres, a quien cuidan y apoyan con los gatos de casa. Reyna se dedica a la crianza de pollos de granja, para esto cuenta con un espacio que tiene una capacidad de 1000 pollos, el cual está ubicado en su propio terreno, para luego venderlo a los comerciantes de los mercados más cercanos donde tiene una clientela que se sabido ganar por sus entregas puntuales y buen servicio . Ésta actividad lo inicio gracias a la idea de su esposo. Espera seguir creciendo y  ampliar su granja y así tener una mayor producción. Antes de empezar con éste negocio, no tenía problemas económicos pero decidió tener esta actividad para sentirse una mujer productiva. Ahora viendo los buenos resultados, desea continuar con su negocio. Este será el préstamo número 06 con Kiva y se siente agradecida de recibir un apoyo financiero para seguir adelante. Con el monto solicitado de 1000 nuevos soles, invertirá en la compra de tripley y otros materiales para construir el hogar de más pollos.
texts.en: Reyna is 25-years-old, is married to Segundo who makes his living in transportation, and is the parent of her only child, who is 6 years of age. Together, they live comfortably in the home of her parents who help care for and provide support for living costs in the home. Reyna makes her living raising chickens. She has a space that has a capacity of 1,000 chickens which is located on her own land. She then sells to merchants in the nearest markets where she has a clientele that she was able to gain due to her punctual deliveries and good service. She does this activity at home thanks to the idea of her husband. She hopes to continue to grow and expand her farm and get a higher output. Before starting this business, she had no financial problems but decided to take this activity to feel like a more productive woman. Now, with her good results, she wants to continue with her business. This will be her 6th Kiva loan and she feels grateful to receive financial support to continue with her work. With the amount requested or 1,000 nuevos soles, she will invest in buying plywood and other materials to build a home for more chickens.

loans.use: to purchase plywood and other materials to make a home for her chickens.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es: María Elena es una mujer muy admirable puesto que a sus 51 años de edad no se cansa de trabajar y luchar por una vida mejor. Habita en casa de su propiedad junto a su esposo  quien se gana la vida como jornalero y así ayuda a sostener la economía de su hogar. María ha logrado adecuar una pequeña tienda en su lugar de residencia  la cual ha sido su fuente de ingresos desde hace mucho tiempo.  Desea hacer algunos arreglos en su vivienda ya que con el tiempo el techo se ha deteriorado y además desea dar final a un cuarto que comenzó y no logró terminar. Solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de lámina galvanizada, madera, ladrillo, arena y cemento. Confía que con los ingresos que percibe de su tienda logrará pagar el crédito.
texts.en: Maria Elena is a very admirable woman since she is 51-years-old and never tires of her work and struggle for a better life. She lives in a house she owns with her husband who makes his living as a laborer, helping to sustain the economy of their home. Maria has managed to make a little shop in her place of residence which has been her source of income for a long time. She wants to make some adjustments in her home because, over time, the roof has deteriorated. She also wants to finish a room that was started but not completed. She has applied for this credit from FUSAI to invest in buying galvanized metal, wood, brick, sand, and cement. She trusts that her earnings from the store will allow her to repay this loan.

loans.use: to purchase galvanized metal, wood, bricks, sand, and cement to repaid her roof and finish a room.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is married with four children who all go to school. She takes care of additional family members. She sells charcoal from home. She sells her goods to all kinds of people on a retail basis. She has been in this business for three years. She works seven days a week. She has applied for a loan of 1,300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy bags of charcoal. Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She aspires to own a delivery van to help with transportation, to become a wholesaler, and to educate her children up to the university level. She resides in a rented house. The family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is 42 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the region of Fort Portal in Uganda. He is married and has four children, with three of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Alfred has been working hard to manage his business where he sells produce. 

To help expand his business, Alfred has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to add to the business and will help Alfred to generate greater profits and to increase his family's standard of living. Alfred hopes that in the future he will be able to expand the business. 

Alfred is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Alfred who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to add to his business and buy more produce

loans.name: Lawrence Thembo

texts.en:
Lawrence Thembo is 35 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the  region of Fort Portal in Uganda. He is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past five years, Lawrence Thembo has been working hard to manage his business selling produce. 

To help expand his business, Lawrence Thembo has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock for the business and will help Lawrence Thembo to generate greater profits and increase on the capital of the business. Lawrence Thembo hopes that in the future he will be able to expand more on the business. 

Lawrence Thembo is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lawrence Thembo who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more stock for the business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is single with six children.  Three of her children go to school. She has no other family members. She sells back cloth at the market. She sells her goods to all kinds of people on a retail basis. She has been in this business for fifteen years. She works six days a week. She gets additional income from selling cooking oil. 

Jane has applied for a loan of 1,200,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more rolls of back cloth.  Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She aspires to educate her children to university level.  

Jane resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but they do not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and food for the family.

loans.use: to buy more rolls of backcloth to sell at the market.

loans.name: Huong

texts.en:
Huong, 45 years old, is married and has one son. She and her husband support the family through the income they earn from making clothes. They began this business 28 years ago. They live in Ho Chi Minh City. 

Huong intends to take a loan to increase her working capital to buy many types of cloth for making clothes to satisfy her customers. The additional materials will enable her to increase her production for sales. She hopes her business will run smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy cloth to make clothes

loans.name: Trinh

texts.en:
Trinh is 47 years old and married with one son. She lives with her family in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City. She and her husband earn income running a general store. 

They started their business five years ago. Trinh intends to take a loan to gradually expand her business by buying a variety of different kinds of confectionery and rice to stock her store and satisfy her customers. 

She hopes her business will run smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a variety of confectionery items and rice to stock her store

loans.name: Tam

texts.en: Tam, 57, lives in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City with her family. Tam and her husband earn money through their business selling slippers. Tam is sometimes unable to provide the volume of slippers required by her customers. Consequently, she would like to get a loan to buy a larger stock of  slippers to meet her customers' needs. She also hopes her business will ensure that her family's living condition will be better.

loans.use: to buy a larger stock of slippers.

loans.name: Perice

texts.en:
Perice is a single woman with two school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food.

For the past two years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling second-hand clothes for children. She cites stiff competition as the major challenge in her business. 

Perice is requesting Kshs 50,000 to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 35 years old and lives in West Point. She’s married and has two children, ages 12 and 15 years old. Her children are in school and live at home. 

For the past four years, Esther has been selling bread. She started this business with a small amount of money from her husband and she learned the business from her mother. What she likes about this business is that it helps her to take care of her children and makes her feel proud of sending her children to school. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bread for her business. Her future plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more bread for her business.

loans.name: Kieu

texts.en:
Kieu, 29 years old, is married and has four children. She and her husband support their family through the income they earn from selling hairdressing tools and cosmetics. They began this business one year ao. They live in Ho Chi Minh City.  

Kieu intends to take a loan to increase her working capital and buy more cosmetics and hairdressing tools for selling. The additional purchase will enable her to increase her sales. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics and hairdressing tools to sell.

loans.name: Dinh

texts.en: Dinh is 33 years old and is married. He has two sons and lives with his family in Ho Chi Minh City. His wife supports the family making and cakes. Dinh has been running a business making incense to sell for two years. He intends to use his loan to buy raw materials in bulk to make incense. He hope his business runs smoothly and will help him to improve his family's living conditions and save money for his children's education.

loans.use: to buy materials to make incense.

loans.name: Nga

texts.en: Nga, 49, lives in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City with her family, including one son and her husband. Nga and her husband earn money through their business producing electrical wire. They started this business ten years ago. Nga would like to get a loan to buy a larger stock of wire and materials to make electrical wire to better meet her customers' needs. She also hopes her business will run smoothly and her living conditions will be better.

loans.use: to buy a larger stock of wire and materials to make electrical wire.

loans.name: Nhung

texts.en:
Nhung, a 45-year-old married woman, lives in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband is a worker. Nhung runs a business that sells a variety of basic goods to people in the local community.

Nhung requests a loan to purchase more products, such as soaps, candies, snack foods, washing powder and shampoos to stock her store. That will enable her to offer a better range of products to her customers. She hopes her business will run smoothly and she can earn additional income to reinvest in her shop and to save for emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase more products, such as soaps, candies, snack foods, washing powder and shampoos to stock her store.

loans.name: Gai's Group

texts.en:
Gai was born in 1958. She lives with her family in Dong Anh, Hanoi. She has two sons. One of them has got married and one is a student. Her husband is a cow-raiser. She is a farmer. She also helps her husband raising cows. She has done this job for years. She earns about 2,500,000 VND per month. Her family’s total earnings are about 7,000,000 VND per month. Her challenge in life and work is lack of capital for raising cows. 

Her dream is to ensure her family’s life and expand her farm in future. This loan is one of steps to help her reach this dream. Gai is a hard-working and dynamic woman. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2003. In this cycle, she would like to borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy more cows to raise. She always wants to expand her farm and get better life.

Other members who are part of Gai's group include the following:
Thuy is 41 years old. She has two children. She has a grocery store. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to expand her store;
Nhuong is 55 years old. She has two children. She is a scrap retailer. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy scrap to sell.

loans.use: to buy more cows to raise.

loans.name: Hoa's Group

texts.en:
Hoa was born in 1962. She lives with her family in Bac Ninh province. She has two children. Her son is a worker and her daughter has gotten married. Her husband is a local agriculture worker, and he also works as a pig raiser.

She sells agricultural inputs to pay for their living. She earns about 4,000,000 VND per month and has done this job for 16 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 13,000,000 VND per month. Her challenge in life and work is the lack of capital to sell agricultural inputs. Her dream is to build up her business and to open a grocery store. This loan is one of steps to help her reach this dream.

Hoa is a hard working woman and also has a passion for her job. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2009. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 10,976,000 VND to sell agricultural products. She always wants to expand her business and have a better life in the future. 

Other members who are part of Hoa's group include the following:

An was born in 1973. She has three children. She has a clothing store and wants to borrow 10,976,000 VND to buy clothing to sell.

Tinh was born in 1977. She has three children. She is a pig and chicken raiser and wants to borrow 10,976,000 VND to buy food for chickens and pigs.

Oanh was born in 1967. She has a child. She sells pillows and blankets to earn a living and wants to borrow 7,392,000 VND to buy pillows and blankets for retailing.

Lan was born in 1991. She has two children. She sells fruits to earn a living and wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to buy fruits to sell.

loans.use: to sell agricultural products

loans.name: Thinh's Group

texts.en:
Thinh was born in 1956. She is now living with her family in Dong Anh, Hanoi. She has two sons and both of them got married. Her sons are carpenters and so is her husband.

She helps her husband in his job and also sells food to earn a living. She earns about 3,000,000 VND per month and has done this job for 10 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 7,000,000 VND per month. Her challenge in life and work are the lack of capital to sell food and the lack of their furniture product’s output. Her dream is to expand her business and to buy more equipment for her house so as to ensure her family’s life. This loan is one of the steps to help her get to this dream.

She will use the money to buy materials for carpentry work and to buy food for selling at breakfast. Thinh is a hard working woman and she has a passion in selling food and helping her husband in his carpentry work. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2004. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy food to sell and buy wood for doing carpentry. She always wants to continue her present job and develop her husband’s career in the future. 

Other members who are part of Thinh's group include the following:

Toi is 58 years old. She has one child. She has a grocery store and wants to borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy rice and household equipment to sell in her store.

Hao is 44 years old. She has two children. She is a chicken raiser and wants to borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy food for the chickens.

Bon is 53 years old. She has three children. She raises chickens and fish to earn a living and wants to borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy and raise chickens and fish.

loans.use: to buy food to sell and buy wood for doing carpentry.

loans.name: Anh's Group

texts.en:
Anh was born in 1983. She lives with her family in Dong Anh, Hanoi. She has three children. One of them is in kindergarten, one is in primary school, and the other is a newborn child. Her husband is a carpenter and so is she. They have been in this profession for over 5 years. Anh earns about 3,000,000 VND per month, and her family’s total earnings are about 8,000,000 VND per month. Her dream is to see her children grow up well and be successful in life. This loan is one of the steps to help her achieve this dream. Anh is a hard-working woman, and she has a passion for her job. She has just joined SEDA in 2013, and this will be her first loan cycle. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy materials for doing carpentry. She always wants to expand her business and raise her children up well. 
Other members who are part of Anh's group include the following:
Yen is 30 years old. She has two children. She is a carpenter. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy materials for carpentry work.
Mui is 46 years old. She has three children. She retails sugarcane to earn a living. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy sugarcane.
San is 34 years old. She has two children. She is a carpenter. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy wood for doing carpentry.
Diep is 26 years old. She has two children. She is a carpenter. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy materials for doing carpentry.

loans.use: to buy materials for doing carpentry.

loans.name: Jose Santos

texts.es: José de 55 años de edad habita en casa de su propiedad junto a su grupo familiar el cual está conformado por su esposa y sus hijos. Desde hace 15 años se dedica a la elaboración y venta de fuegos artificiales. Este negocio es su principal fuente de ingresos y gracias a su responsabilidad y carisma tiene muchos clientes quienes cada día lo prefieren más. Su deseo es ampliar y reparar el cuarto de la cocina ya que es pequeña y la lámina se encuentra deteriorada. Por lo anterior solicita este crédito a FUSAI para comprar lámina, madera, cemento y pintura y comenzar lo antes posible a reparar su cocina.
texts.en: Jose, 55, lives in a house owned by his family group which consists of his wife and children. For 15 years, he has made his living making and selling fireworks. This business is his family's main source of income. With his responsibility and charisma, he has many customers and everyday he gains more. His desire is to expand and repair the kitchen area of his house because it is small and the laminate is deteriorated. Therefore, he came to FUSAI to request this loan to buy laminate, wood, cement, and paint to start to repair his kitchen as soon as possible.

loans.use: to purchase laminate, wood, cement, and pain to repair his kitchen.

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
Lawrence is 46 years old and lives in the town of Mpigi in the region of Kampala South in Uganda. He is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past two years, Lawrence has been working hard to manage his maize milling business, which deals in grinding maize for floor and produce.

To help expand his business, Lawrence has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more machines for the milling process, and will help Lawrence to generate greater profits and increase his income. Lawrence hopes that in the future, he will be able to expand his business. 

Lawrence is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lawrence who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more machines for the milling process.

loans.name: Xuyen's Group

texts.en:
Xuyen was born in 1980. She lives with her family in Bac Ninh. She has three children. Two of them are in secondary school, and the youngest is in kindergarten. Her husband is a key repairman. She raises chickens and sells groceries to earn a living. She has done these jobs for 3 years. She earns about 5,000,000 VND per month. Her family’s total income is about 10,000,000 VND per month.

Her challenge in life and work is lacking capital to raise chickens. Her dream is to expand her business and have a better life in the future. This loan is one step towards helping her reach this dream. Xuyen is a hard working woman. She also has a passion for her business. She said that these jobs help her earn more money and have time to take care of her family. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2011. In this cycle, she would like to borrow 9,184,000 VND to sell groceries. She always wants to improve her family’s life, expand her business, and save money for her children's education.

Other members who are part of Xuyen’s group include the following:

Phuong was born in 1964. She has two children. She is a farmer. She wants to borrow 10,080,000 VND to raise chickens. 

Phuong was born in 1983. She has two children. She is a carpenter. She wants to borrow 10,080,000 VND to raise chickens and pigs. 

Lien was born in 1983. She has two children. She is a farmer. She is a pig and chicken raiser. She wants to borrow 10,080,000 VND to raise pigs and chickens.
 
Phu was born in 1968. She has two children. She is a farmer. She wants to borrow 10,080,000 VND to buy chickens and pigs to raise.
 
Duy was born in 1981. She has two children. She works at a garment company. She wants to borrow 10,528,000 VND to raise chickens.

loans.use: to sell groceries.

loans.name: Quy's Group

texts.en:
Quy was born in 1960. She lives with her family in Bac Ninh. She has two daughters and a son. One of her daughters is married, the other is studying in Korea and her son is a dentist. Her husband is a pork seller.  She sells soybeans to earn a living. She has done this job for 20 years. She earns about 4,000,000 VND per month. Her family’s total earnings are about 8,000,000 VND per month. Her challenge in life and work is a lack of capital to sell soybeans. Her dream is to expand her business and have a better life in future. This loan is one of the steps in helping her to reach this dream. Quy is a hard working and careful woman. She also has passion for her business because with this job, she can earn more money to pay for living expenses while having time to take care of her family. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2007. In this cycle, she would like to borrow 11,872,000 VND to sell soybeans. She wants to develop her business and have a better life in the future. 
Other members who are part of Quy’s group include the following:
Duyen is 30 years old. She has three children. She sells tofu to pay for living expenses. She wants to borrow 10,528,000 VND to buy materials to produce tofu.
Doan is 47 years old. She has two children. She is a carpenter. She wants to borrow 10,528,000 VND to buy materials for doing carpentry. 
Hien is 38 years old. She has three children. She has a grocery store. She wants to borrow 10,528,000 VND to buy rice and household equipment to sell in her store.
Lien is 38 years old. She has two children. She leases dishes to earn a living. She wants to borrow 10,528,000 VND to buy dishes for renting.

loans.use: to sell soybeans.

loans.name: Hue's Group

texts.en:
Hue was born in 1978, and she is now living with her family in Bac Ninh. She has two children who are attending primary and secondary school, and her husband is a construction worker. She sells food for a living, earning about 3,000,000 VND per month. She has done this job for 15 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 3,500,000 VND per month. 

Her challenges in life and work are that she lacks capital to sell food, and she lacks money to pay for her children’s education. Her dreams are to expand her business and that her children will be successful in life. This loan is one of the steps to help her achieve these dreams. Hue is a hard-working woman. She also has a passion for her job because it’s flexible, giving her more time to take care of her children. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2012. In the last loan cycle, she borrowed 5,152,000 VND and repaid it on time. In this cycle, she would like to borrow 6,944,000 VND to sell food. She always wants to expand her business, save the profits for her children’s education, and improve her family’s life.

Other members who are part of Hue's group include the following:
Hanh is 40 years old. She has four children and sells electronic goods to earn a living. She wants to borrow 6,944,000 VND to sell electronic goods.
Nhung is 30 years old. She has three children sells food for a living. She wants to borrow 6,944,000 VND to sell food.
Thuoc is 54 years old. She has five children and retails scrap to earn a living. She wants to borrow 6,944,000 VND to retail scrap.

loans.use: to sell food.

loans.name: Ngat's Group

texts.en:
Ngat was born in 1976. She is now living with her family in Bac Ninh. She has two sons who are studying at secondary school and high school. Her husband is a construction worker. She sells clothing to earn a living, which she has done for 8 years. She earns about 4,000,000 VND per month and her family’s total earnings are about 9,000,000 VND per month. Her challenge in life and work is the lack of capital to sell clothing. Her dreams are to expand her business and that her children are successful in life. This loan is one the of steps to help her achieve this dream. Ngat is a hard-working and careful woman. She also has a passion for her job. She said that this job helps her to earn more money to pay for living expenses and make herself more dynamic. She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2007. In the last loan cycle, she borrowed 10,080,000 VND and repaid on time. In this cycle, she would like to borrow 11,424,000 VND to sell clothing. She always wants to expand her business, improve her family’s life and save the profits for her children’s education. 

Other members who are part of Ngat's group include the following:

Minh is 46 years old. She has two children. She has a grocery store. She wants to borrow 11,424,000 VND to expand her business.

Thua is 39 years old. She has four children. She grow vegetables to pay for living. She wants to borrow 11,424,000 VND to grow vegetables.

Anh is 30 years old. She has two children. She sells pork to earn a living. She wants to borrow 11,424,000 VND to sell pork.

Xuyen is 30 years old. She has three children. She raises pigs to earn a living. She wants to borrow 11,424,000 VND to raise pigs.

Mai is 43 years old. She has two children. She sells household equipment to earn a living. She wants to borrow 11,424,000 VND to expand her business.

Lieu is 44 years old. She has two children. She buys and sells scrap to earn a living. She wants to borrow 10,976,000 VND to sell scrap.

loans.use: to sell clothing.

loans.name: Yamileth Del Socorro

texts.es:
Yamileth de 37 años de edad, casada con tres hijos menores de edad de 15, 12, 3 anos es originaria de Managua, lugar que está ubicado en la zona central del país. Ella se caracteriza por ser trabajara, responsable con ganas de superación personal. Lamentablemente no pudo cursar estudio por falta de recursos económicos, por  lo tanto en la actualidad lucha día a día para brindarles un futuro mejor a sus hijos y formarlos en profesionales.

Gracias a su esfuerzo y sus ganas de salir adelante tiene por actividad económica una pulpería, es una pequeña tienda que vende productos varios  y comestibles en cantidades pequeñas como: frijoles, azúcar, arroz, huevos, galletas meneítos, jugos fósforos, cigarrillos, dulces, gaseosas, sazonadores, papel higiénico. Ella dedica a su negocio unas 12 horas diarias ofreciendo su producto. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra y venta de productos varios y comestibles para que en un futuro no muy lejano pueda obtener mejores ingresos. Yamileth agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Yamileth is 37-years-old, married with three children aged 15, 12, and 3, and she is a native of Managua, a city that is located in the central region of the country. She is characterized as being hardworking and responsible with goals of personal improvement. Unfortunately, she could not study for the lack of financial resources so now she is struggling everyday to provide a better future for her children and to transform them into professionals.  
Thanks to her effort and her desire to succeed, she has a business that is a general shop. It is a small store that sells various products and foodstuffs such as beans, sugar, eggs, Meneitos brand snack crackers, juices, matches, cigarettes, candy, soda, spices, and toilet paper. She works in her store 12 hours a day offering her products. The purpose of her loan is to invest in working capital to stock her business with the purchase of various products to sell so that they can have a better income in the near future. Yamileth acknowledges the assistance that the investors of Kiva provide to poor people in poor countries such as Nicaragua to help them have a more dignified working environment.

loans.use: to invest in working capital to stock her store with various products and foodstuffs such as beans, sugar, rice, eggs, crackers, and more.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a 26-year-old businesswoman in Embu. She is married to Martin. They are blessed with one child, who is two years old. Esther has been selling charcoal for the past two years with a monthly income of 16,000 KES, which she uses to support her family. 

Esther is applying for her second loan term with KADET after repaying her previous loan successfully. She will use the loan to purchase more charcoal. With the anticipated profits from the business, she will better the living standards of her family. 

Her hopes and dreams are to run a successful charcoal business.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en:
Gertrude is married with five children, all of whom go to school. She cares for three additional family members (three orphans). She sells African attire on a retail and wholesale basis at the market. She has been this in business for ten years. She works six days a week. She gets additional income from providing bridal services. 

Gertrude has applied for a loan of 1,400,000 UGX from MCDT-SACCO to buy bales of African attire and nursery school clothing. Her major business challenges include seasonality and transportation. She is aspiring to start importing African attire from the Democratic Republic of Congo and also to become a wholesaler. She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity, but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses includes bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy  bales of African attire.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 40-year-old married mother of three children, ages 15, 10, and 5 years old. Her spouse is Joseph. She earns a living for her family by operating a retail shop. Her business is only marginally sustainable because she is unable to expand it. Her goal is to fully stock her shop in order to attract more customers and increase her profits. 

Grace is requesting a loan from KADET LTD in order to stock her shop with rice, sugar, washing detergent, maize meal, cooking oil and cereals. With the additional income that she will earn from this improvement, she will reinvest in her business and use the remaining amount to repay her loan. 

In the future, Grace plans to continue to invest in her business and to eventually operate a larger, wholesale store and purchase a plot to construct a permanent house for her family.

loans.use: to stock her shop with rice, sugar, washing detergent, maize meal, cooking oil and cereals.

loans.name: Ephys

texts.en:
Ephys is a 55-year-old businessman and is married to Monica. Ephys has been in the transportation business for the past 15 years, with a monthly income of 60,000 KES, which he uses to support his family. 

Ephys is applying for his third loan with KADET, after repaying the previous loans successfully. He will use the loan to service his vehicle. With the anticipated profits, he will improve the living standards of his family and repay his loan. 

His hopes and dreams are to have a sustainable business.

loans.use: to service his vehicle.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is a divorced woman with two children; both attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over six years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers by. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan Patience wants to purchase stocks of green vegetables, fruit, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of green vegetables, fruit, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Dinah

texts.en:
Dinah is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rental bills and school fees.

For over one year, she has operated a fruit stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers by. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 loan she wants to purchase stocks of bananas, oranges and mangoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of bananas, oranges and mangoes for resale.

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura, a married woman who has been blessed with six school-going children, lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Laura operates a charcoal-selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high cost of transportation. Having joined Yehu to get financial support, Laura is requesting a loan of Kshs 25,000 to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Ammar Group

texts.en: This group is called Ammar and consists of four ladies. Rawya is 41 years old. She lives with her two children in Aden, Yemen. She makes a living selling clothing, electronic materials and other things. She decided to establish her business because she saw it as profitable. She is requesting a loan of 60,000 Yemen Rials (YER) from AMB to buy clothing, electronic materials, etc., for expanding her business. She states that this loan will be of help because she will be able to develop her business. This will increase her sales, generating greater earnings at the same time. She has future plans to make improvements to her house in order to have a better standard of living.

loans.use: to buy clothing, electronic materials, etc., for expanding her business.

loans.name: Jaytun

texts.en:
Jaytun lives with her husband, Rafique, and their child in the small town of Mayanaguri in Jalpaiguri. Her child is studying in class 1. She has completed her education until V (grade 5). She is a homemaker and her husband is running his own electrical wiring business. Right now, her husband’s business is not running smoothly due to insufficient equipment (wire, switches, plugs, etc.) and that is affecting their financial condition. So she decided to take a loan and try to purchase a lot of the equipment needed for her husband's business and help him to earn more profit with his business. This business will be profitable for them because during construction, electrical wiring is needed.  

Her dream is to give a proper education to her child and make their family strong financially. Though she is a homemaker, she helps her husband in his business as much as she can. She is a dedicated woman. She is very happy to become a member of BJS and very thankful to Kiva for funding her loan.

loans.use: To buy wire, plugs, switches, etc. for her husband's electrical business.

loans.name: Kaydee

texts.en:
This is Kaydee from Liberia.  She resides in Buchanan, the capital city of Grand Bassa County in Liberia.  The county is located by the sea and is known for its beaches and fish.  In addition, many logging companies are also located in the city.  People in Buchanan are known in the country for their love of fufu, a cassava based dough typically eaten with soup or sauce. 

Kaydee is 41 and married with six children.  Her children's ages range from 13 to 26.  They all are currently living at home and only three are in school.  

Kaydee owns her own small local shop business selling plastic goods such as buckets, plates, bowls, pans, etc.  Sh has been in this business for the past 17 years.  She will use the loan proceeds to purchase more plastic goods.
  
On average, Kaydee works twelve hours per day at her business from Monday to Saturday.  She started her business with a small amount of money from her husband. She transports her merchandise by shared taxi.  She cites the rainy season as the biggest challenge to the business.  Her favourite part of her business is the profit.  In the future, she would like to build a modern house.  

She is grateful for your support!

loans.use: to purchase more plastic household goods to sell.

loans.name: Dantiande 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  DANTIANDE  1 sont toutes  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  49 ans, 7 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  Bandiagara, 5ème région administrative du Mali. 
Bandiagara est une localité constituée à 90%  de falaise où les femmes ont comme activité principale la culture d’oignon et de sa transformation. Les femmes transportent de la terre arable sur les hauteurs afin de confectionner leurs planches destinées à leurs pratiques agricoles. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités maraîchères en cette fin d’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur  1 er prêt avec l’institution.
La spéculation cultivée est essentiellement l’oignon avec   Fatouma S   assise en première  position de la droite  vers la gauche sur la photo. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter  de la semence et des engrais. La production est vendue au niveau du village et de Bandiagara, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 21.000  Francs CFA en fin de campagne Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’aider son mari dans les dépenses familiales d’acheter  de petits ruminants et vollailes  et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group "DANTIANDE 1" are all married women, who average 49 years of age and seven children each, all living in polygamous families in Bandiagara, in the 5th administrative region of the Republic of Mali. Bandiagara as a town is 90% cliffs. There, the women's main work involves growing onions and processing them. The women transport arable earth uphill to make planting beds for their farm work. 

They are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their market garden work as the rainy season ends. They are on their first loan with the institution.

The crop grown is essentially onions, as is the case with Fatouma S, who is sitting first from the right in the photo. With her loan, she intends to purchase some seeds and fertilizer. After the harvest, the produce is sold to men and women customers in the village and in Bandiagara.

She plans on making a profit of 21,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting effort. This profit will allow her to help out her husband in covering family expenses, to purchase small ruminants and poultry, and to invest the rest in her work.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Dantiande 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  DANTIANDE 3 sont toutes  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  48 ans, 7 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  Bandiagara, 5ème région administrative du Mali. 
Bandiagara est une localité constituée à 90%  de falaise où les femmes ont comme activité principale la culture d’oignon et de sa transformation. Les femmes transportent de la terre arable sur les hauteurs afin de confectionner leurs planches destinées à leurs pratiques agricoles. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités maraîchères en cette fin d’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur1er  prêt avec l’institution.
La spéculation cultivée est essentiellement l’oignon avec   Dimbé Indé   debout en 2eme  position de la dela gauche vers la droite sur la photo. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter  de la semence et des engrais. La production est vendue au niveau du village et de Bandiagara, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 21.000  Francs CFA en fin de campagne Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’aider son mari dans les dépenses familiales, d’acheter de petits ruminants et vollailes  et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Dantiande 3 group are all married women with an average age of 48 years and an average of 7 children each. They all live in polygamous families in Bandiagara, in the 5th administrative region of Mali. Bandiagara is a region made up of 90% hilly areas where the women run their primary business of raising onions and producing byproducts.

The women transport arable soil into the hills in order to craft crop beds for their farming business. They have partnered with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso in order to better run their vegetable businesses during this end of the rainy season. This is their first loan with the organization.

Dimbé Indé, pictured standing second from left to right in the photo, is in the onion business. With her loan, she plans to purchase fertilizer and seeds. She sells her crops both in the village and in Bandiagara after her harvest, to a customer base made up of both men and women. She hopes to earn a profit of 21,000 francs CFA at the end of the season, which will allow her to help her husband with the family expenses, purchasing small livestock and poultry, and reinvesting the remainder in her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Dantiande 4 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe   DANTIANDE 4 sont toutes  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  41 ans, 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  Bandiagara, 5ème région administrative du Mali.

Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités maraîchères en cette fin d’hivernage.

Bandiagara as a town is 90% cliffs. There, the women's main work involves growing onions and processing them. The women transport arable earth uphill to make planting beds for their farm work. 

They are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their market garden work as the rainy season ends. They are on their first loan with the institution.

The crop grown is essentially onions, as is the case with Habibatou, who is standing first from the right in the photo. With her loan, she intends to purchase some seeds and fertilizer. After the harvest, the produce is sold to men and women customers in villages and in Bandiagara.

She plans on making a profit of 22,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting effort. This profit will allow her to help out her husband in covering family expenses, to purchase small ruminants and poultry, and to invest the rest in her work.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Kende 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe   KENDE 1 sont toutes  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  45 ans, 7 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  Bandiagara, 5ème région administrative du Mali. 
Bandiagara est une localité constituée à 90%  de falaise où les femmes ont comme activité principale la culture d’oignon et de sa transformation. Les femmes transportent de la terre arable sur les hauteurs afin de confectionner leurs planches destinées à leurs pratiques agricoles.

Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités maraîchères en cette fin d’hivernage.

texts.en:
The members of the DIANOU 3 group are all married women, averaging 46 years old with 6 children. They live in polygamous families in Bandiagara, in the 5th administrative region of Mali. 

Ninety percent of the village of Bandiagara is made up of cliffs, and the women’s main business is growing and processing onions. The women transport arable soil to the tops of the hills in order to create planting beds for their farm work.

They are working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to complete their farming tasks as the rainy season ends. This is their first loan with the institution.

Ada Hama is seated 2nd from the right in the photo. With her loan, she intends to buy seeds and fertilizer. After the harvest, she sells what she produces in the village and in Bandiagara to male and female customers. 

She plans on earning 22,000 CFA Francs by the end of the season. This income will enable her to help her husband with family expenses (children’s schooling fees, health care and food) and to buy some small ruminants and poultry, and re-invest the rest in her business.

texts.en:
The members of the Gagnaka 3 group are married women averaging 48 years of age, with six children. They all live in polygamous families in Bandiagara, the fifth administrative region of Mali. Bandiagara is a locality 90% of which is covered by cliffs. The local women mainly grow onions and preserve them. The women carry arable soil up the slopes in order to have their vegetables beds set up. The group members collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to better manage their agricultural activities at the end of the rainy season.

They are on their first loan with Soro Yiriwaso. They basically grow onions, which is what Korka does, for example. She is the first one seated from left to right in the photo. With her loan, she plans to buy seeds and fertilizers. After being harvested, the produce is sold in the village and in Bandiagara, to a mixed clientele. She plans to earn 22,000 West African francs at the end of the agricultural cycle. This revenue will allow her to help her husband with family expenses, buy small [tools?] and reinvest the rest in her business.

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  GAGNAKA 4 sont toutes  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  44 ans, 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  Bandiagara, 5ème région administrative du Mali. 
Bandiagara est une localité constituée à 90%  de falaise où les femmes ont comme activité principale la culture d’oignon et de sa transformation. Les femmes transportent de la terre arable sur les hauteurs afin de confectionner leurs planches destinées à leurs pratiques agricoles. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités maraîchères en cette fin d’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur  1er prêt avec l’institution.
La spéculation cultivée est essentiellement l’oignon avec   Seguelem   debout en 2eme   position de la gauche vers  la droite sur la photo.

texts.en:
The members of the Gagnaka 4 group are all married women who are on average 44 years old with five children. They live in polygamous families in Bandiagara, in the fifth administrative region of Mali.
Bandiagara is a locality that is made up of 90 % cliffs where the women have as their principal activity, onion growing and conditioning. The women transport the arable earth to the uplands in order to make their boards for their farming activities.
They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution in order to manage their market gardening activities during the winter.
This is their first loan from the institution.
The main crop that is grown by Seguelem, who is standing second from the left in the photo, is onions.
With her loan she plans to buy seeds and fertiliser. She sells the production in the village and in Bandiagara after harvesting, to her customers who are both men and women.
She hopes to make a profit of 23.000 Francs CFA by the end of the season. This profit will enable her to help her husband with the family expenses (school fees for the children, health and food costs), to buy little ruminants and fowl, and invest the rest in her business.

loans.use: To buy fertiliser and seeds.

Bandiagara est une localité constituée à 90%  de falaise où les femmes ont comme activité principale la culture d’oignon et de sa transformation. Les femmes transportent de la terre arable sur les hauteurs afin de confectionner leurs planches destinées à leurs pratiques agricoles. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités maraîchères en cette fin d’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur 1er prêt avec l’institution.
La spéculation cultivée est essentiellement l’oignon avec   Adenné  debout en 3eme position de la gauche vers la droite.

texts.en:
The members of the Kani Gogouna 1 group are all married women with an average age of 46 years and 6 children each. They all live in polygamous families in Bandiagara in the 5th administrative region of Mali. Bandiagara is a 90% hilly region where the women are in the business of raising onions and producing byproducts. The women transport arable soil into the hills in order to create crop beds for their agricultural businesses.

The women have partnered with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso in order to better run their vegetable businesses during this end of the rainy season. They are on their first loan with the organization.

Adenné, pictured standing 3rd from left to right, is in the onion business. With her loan, she plans on purchasing seeds and fertilizer. She sells her crops in the village and in Bandiagara after the harvest, to a customer base made up of both men and women. She hopes to earn a profit of 23,000 francs CFA at the end of the season. This will allow her to help her husband with the family expenses (education for their children, health, and food) and purchasing small livestock and poultry, and to invest the rest in her business.
